channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Private Equity, Saddled With Investments It Can’t Sell, Loses Its Luster
item.description: As funds deliver mediocre returns and sheds investors, the industry is struggling to unload 31,000 investments, an increase over this time last year.

item.title: Google Cloud chief reveals the long game: a decade of silicon and the energy battle behind the AI boom
item.description: "We've worked on TPUs since 2014 ... a long time before AI was fashionable," Thomas Kurian said at the Fortune Brainstorm AI conference.

item.title: May Britt, 91, Dies; Her Marriage to Sammy Davis Jr. Sparked Outrage
item.description: She was a white actress, he was a popular Black entertainer, and their relationship elicited racist reactions in 1960, worrying John F. Kennedy’s pres...

item.title: OpenAI’s CEO Sam Altman says in 10 years’ time college graduates will be working ‘some completely new, exciting, super well-paid’ job in space
item.description: While Bill Gates has said the two-day workweek could come within the next decade, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman says Gen Alpha college graduates will be too b...

item.title: Why restricting graduate loans will bankrupt America’s talent supply chain
item.description: The K-shaped divide is no longer confined to the labor market. It’s now embedded in its foundation: education.

item.title: Rotating Cast of Wall Street Figures Were Listed as Executors of Epstein’s Will
item.description: Copies of Jeffrey Epstein’s last will and testament show that the convicted sex offender and disgraced financier provide a real-time glimpse of the po...

item.title: 6 ‘unhinged’ things Spanx founder Sara Blakely did that ultimately shaped the success of her $1.2 billion empire
item.description: Blakely became the first self-made female billionaire in 2012.

item.title: What We Get Wrong About Christian Nationalism
item.description: The irony of our secular age is that theology is more powerful than ever.

item.title: A huge chunk of U.S. GDP growth is being kept alive by AI spending ‘with no guaranteed return,’ Deutsche Bank says
item.description: “Investment in AI-related sectors is critical to GDP growth [and the] US would be close to recession this year if it weren’t for tech-related spending...

item.title: Yemen’s Warring Sides Agree to Largest Prisoner Swap in a Decade of Fighting
item.description: The Houthi rebels and the internationally recognized government plan to exchange about 2,900 detainees, a rare humanitarian win at a time of deepening...

item.title: Federal Prosecutor Was Surprised by Trump’s Flights on Epstein’s Jet
item.description: A 2020 email noted that Donald Trump was listed as a passenger on Jeffrey Epstein’s jet at least eight times from 1993 to 1996.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Arrested at U.K. Protest Supporting Palestine Action Prisoners
item.description: The Swedish activist Greta Thunberg was arrested after holding a sign that the police said showed support for the group Palestine Action, which Britai...

item.title: The Strange Case of the Russian Snickers in U.K. Convenience Shops
item.description: The Russian-labeled candy bars are a reminder of how difficult it is to completely disconnect a major economy from the global flow of goods.

item.title: Russia Bombards Ukraine Hours After Zelensky Calls Peace Plan ‘Quite Solid’
item.description: The Ukrainian leader cited progress on security guarantees, even as Russia bombed Ukraine overnight, indicating that the Kremlin is prepared to contin...

item.title: Italian Artisans Add Figurines of Donald Trump to Nativity Scenes
